I was about to write out an entire novel on just the part he said about maps, but then I just stopped. I thought about it for a second, and realized that, in a view about maps, players of Call of Duty are really split in three, which will now be revealed below. First, you got the run and gunners: You all know these people. Lightweight on almost every class; extreme conditioning and dexterity; fast hands and toughness etc etc. Woodsy gave a very accurate of one's thoughts on large maps if they like run and gunning: "Oh my dear God, when am I going to find someone to shoot?" From what I've seen, people that prefer running and shooting / spraying and preying (not praying) make up the large majority of players in this game, voting for every small map they see (e.g. Nuketown 2025) Next, you got the long shots. I don't see people like this very often, but long shots (campers, headglitchers, whatever you want to call them) hang in a house, tree, corner, grassy areas, or just plain back of a choke point and shoot every single man they see. Black Ops 2 seemed to strengthen this minority with Target Finders and found a way to counter it with the MMS attachment, but I still find it very common to see someone use a sniper rifle over an automatic weapon (even though I count the SVU-AS as an automatic weapon because of how some people use it). Quick Scoping players are VERY strong, however it's glorious to me to find someone going, simply put, "old schooler" sniping. Let us use Standoff as an example. There's a large open choke point in the middle, and two buildings with a perfect view of everyone's heads. These snipers will pull out their secondaries and fight over those houses and end up dominating the choking space. There are also people like me, dubbed "Mobile Snipers," who lay down on a grassy knoll, kill about two people, and move on to the next grassy knoll. You see, these people love large and open maps because they bring fresh kill aplenty, and tend to hate people that find out their hiding spot and constantly kill them each life over, and over, and over. Finally, you have the people that prefer both. I fit in this group, because I have half long range classes and half running and gunning classes that I find incredibly entertaining to use. I think this group is definitely the minority in the Black Ops II player space, and probably got the accolade, "Evolver" the most in Modern Warfare 3. What I end up doing early in a round on a big map like Turbine is pick two classes that would fit it. One to rush to a point on the back of the map, and then one to protect the point, or pointS if we're dominating. I've found people like this tend to enjoy objective-based game modes and will still lean one way or another in respect of the last two. I, myself, have realized that all of my classes tend to be ranged (not to mention I hate using shotguns, 'cept for the KSG.) Edit: The middle paragraph / subject was a giant wall of text, fixed it so that it's easier on the eyes.

I think the main thing is that you're thinking about it too much. Sometimes, when you cloud your head with an objective and try to do something else like, say, defending a bomb point, you end up choking and dying more often. If you often catch yourself thinking or saying to yourself, "Oh my God, one more kill and I get that Bloodthirsty!" then you're thinking about your own objective too much. Before playing a game, take a deep breath to clear your mind. Say to yourself, "I'm going to complete this game of _______ and win," and there's a bigger chance that you'll get your Bloodthirsties faster since you aren't overthinking your strategies.

WRITING.TITLE: What are your favorite things to say as the last innocent to the Traitors that are overwhelming you?
WRITING.TEXT: Preferably over a mic, so that it feels more real. I, personally, pull the overly stupid Bane card on my main server; it allows the innocents to camp, however not the Detectives or T's. Most often I scare the Traitors off with mass amounts of testosterone-filled manliness (i.e. fleeing like a pussy into the captain's quarters on roy_the_ship) and they plant C4 near me to get me out. It's then I break out my cup specialized for Bane and just say, "Oh, you think C4 is your ally. I was born in it, molded by it. I never saw the explosion until I was already a man, and by thing it was BLINDING!" Once the final note in, "BLINDING!" was out, I'd rush out of the room and continue to charge every living thing that comes in my path with a Shotgun or an M16.

An old pirate or a sailor. It's an idea my friends and I toss around every now and then, our most popular power idea being a harpoon (preferably hand-thrown). There's a bunch of different ways a harpoon ability could work. The two ideas I like the most are 1. Move slower for a few seconds as you aim and charge the harpoon, then throw it at a survivor. If it hits the target, then you yank it back a few meters, dragging the survivor with it. or 2. Having it so the Harpoon has a short range but can injure survivors. If you hit an injured survivor with it, then they're put into the A-D wiggle state as you drag them back onto your shoulder for later hook placement (Wiggle progress carrying over once the dragging's done). 'Course these are just rough ideas and probably wouldn't translate well into the game, it's just nice to think about some terrifying music playing as you watch yourself get pulled back by an old moldy rope before being put onto an old rusty hook.

WRITING.TITLE: Anxious about a job
WRITING.TEXT: I dropped out of college in April and I still don't have a job. Every time I plan out the day to try and ease myself into pushing in an application or when I get ready to leave I just shut down. The farthest I've ever gotten was halfway through getting dressed but ended up psyching myself out, crawled into bed and didn't get out for the rest of the day. I don't even know what I'm worried about, but my brain still gets put out like a wet candle when I start thinking about going to these things. Are there any exercises out there I can do to maybe calm me down when I feel like this? I want to stop being a burden to my family so badly.

WRITING.TITLE: My dog is most likely starting to die and i won't know for sure until i'm not around him
WRITING.TEXT: Hey, I'm 19M and I've been dealing with my anxiety for the last couple years. It's flared up badly before but not as badly as this past week. My mom and I have three dogs; a Dane and two labs. One of the labs started bleeding from his mouth and we took him to the vet, who told her immediately that there was a big tumor in his gums that started to bleed. It grew very fast, it wasn't there when he went to the vet last month-ish, so the vet said it was likely to be cancer. Two days ago they just cut out the tumor, and they're doing a biopsy right now. We won't get the results back until they call us next week, which is right in the middle of a vacation we're going to take to visit our family. I don't know if I'm going to be able to relax at all until the results get back, and if the results come back with bad news I'm going to be very distressed. I love this dog, he's only 4 years old and he's done so much for me. He spent almost the entirety of every day comforting me in my bed after I got in a car crash, he's the first thing to try and cuddle with you if he sees you're sad. Every time I get reminded about his situation I stress out, get flustered, and start breathing heavily. I know I can't fight the inevitable. I just want to know if there's anything I can do to help cope with it.

Thank you for your kind words, it really means a lot. I talked to my boyfriend about it a little bit and it helped me calm down a little more than how on-edge I was writing this post. The vacation we're taking is to New England, halfway across the country. My mom and I talked it over and said if the news coming back was bad we would consider going back home to get him treatment asap. I can't remember everything the vet was saying but one of the treatments was basically taking out a chunk of his face where the cancer was, leaving him a bit of a dent on his snoot but with a chance of avoiding doomsday for at least few more years. Reading around said dogs responded pretty well to that treatment, which makes me feel a lot better, too. I just can't not think of the worst happening. Him having cancer, the treatment not working, leaving him deformed and progressively more sick until we decide it's best to put him down. There's no way we could afford something like chemo. Thank you again for your well-wishes.

gt;I feel like the suggested change is awful for one core reason: it requires Survivors to take Self-Care or a Medkit I think you are misunderstanding the suggestion. There are four (4) survivors in each game, who can **heal each other.** It'd be no more required to bring Self Care or a medkit than it would be against any other killer.

WRITING.TITLE: Having trouble with explaining thoughts
WRITING.TEXT: I don't have insurance and I work part-time, so I can't exactly afford the greatest therapy. I went to a few sessions for my anxiety at a local university that offered counselling for $10 a session, but honestly the pressure I felt of adding another thing to my weekly schedule pushed me to stop them after about four of them. One thing that stuck with me though was when my therapist tried getting me to help him understand what I'm thinking when I start to panic in public but I just can't ever seem to put it into words. They're not, like, *conscious* thoughts, it feels like it all happens at once and it's not like I can just pick out sentences that I'm thinking to myself *because they're not there.* Surely I'm not the only person who's had this experience? If someone's gotten past this blockade, can you share your breakthrough so it can help some others in the future?
